ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.2_0: At one time Assaji and Punabbasuka were the resident monks at Kīṭāgiri. They were bad and shameless.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.3_0: and they were misbehaving in this way:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.4_0: They planted flowering trees, watered and plucked them, and then tied the flowers together.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.5_0: They made the flowers into garlands, garlands with stalks on one side and garlands with stalks on both sides.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.6_0: They made flower arrangements, wreaths, ornaments for the head, ornaments for the ears, and ornaments for the chest. And they had others do the same.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.7_0: They then took these things, or sent them, to the women, the daughters, the girls, the daughter-in-laws, and the female slaves of good families.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.8_0: They ate from the same plates as these women and drank from the same vessels.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.9_0: They sat on the same seats as them, and they lay down on the same beds, on the same sheets, under the same covers, and both on the same sheets and under the same covers.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.10_0: They ate at the wrong time, drank alcohol, and wore garlands, perfumes, and cosmetics.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.11_0: They danced, sang, played instruments, and performed.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.1.12_0: While the women were dancing, singing, playing instruments, and performing, so would they.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.2.1_0: They played various games: board games with eight and ten rows, imaginary board games, hopscotch, spillikins, dice games, tip-cat, painting-with-the-hand games, ball games, toy-pipe games, toy-plow games, turning somersaults, toy-windmill games, toy-measure games, toy-carriage games, toy-bow games, letter-guessing gamessing games, thought-guessing deformities.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.2.2_0: They trained in elephant riding, in horsemanship, in carriage riding, in archery, in swordsmanship.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.2.3_0: And they ran in front of elephants, in front of horses, and in front of carriages, and they ran backwards and forwards.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.2.4_0: They whistled, clapped their hands, wrestled, and boxed.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.2.5_0: They spread their outer robe on a stage and said to the dancing girls, “Sisters, and they won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.3.1_0: Just then a certain monk who had completed the rains residence in Kāsī was on his way to visit the Buddha at Kīṭāgiri.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.3.2_0: In the morning he robed up, took his bowl and robe, and entered Kīṭāgiri to collect almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.3.3_0: He was pleasing in the way he entered and returned, in looking at and in looking away, in drawing in and stretching out his arms; his eyes were lowered, and he was perfect in deportment.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.3.4_0: When people saw him, they said, “Who is this, acting like a fool, like a dullard, continuously frowning?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.3.4_1: Who will give almsfood to him?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.3.4_2: Almsfood should instead be given to our Venerables Assaji and Punabbasuka, for they are gentle, congenial, pleasant to speak with, greeting one with a smile, welcoming, friendly, open, the first to speak.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.3.4_3: The alms-food should be given to them.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.3.5_0: a certain lay follower saw him wandering for alms.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.3.6_0: Having seen (that), he went to that monk,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.3.6_1: He went to him and said, “Venerable Sir, a almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.3.7_0: “It’s not possible that Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja gains.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.4.1_0: He took that monk to his house and gave him a meal.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.4.3_0: “I’m going to Sāvatthī to visit the Buddha.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.4.4_0: “Well then, would you please pay respect at the feet of the Buddha in my name and say,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.4.5_0: ‘Venerable Sir, the monastery in Kīṭāgiri has been corrupted.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.4.6_0: Assaji and Punabbasuka are the resident monks there. They are bad and shameless,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.4.7_0: and they were misbehaving in this way:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.4.8_0: They planted flowering trees, watered and plucked them, and then tied the flowers together.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.4.9_0: Those people who previously had faith and confidence have now lost it,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.4.10_0: that there is no longer any support for the Sangha,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.4.11_0: and that the good monks have left and the bad monks are staying on?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.4.12_0: Sir, please send monks to stay at the monastery at Kīṭāgiri.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.1_0: The monk consented, got up, and left for Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.2_0: When he eventually arrived, he went to the Buddha in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.3_0: Since it is the custom for Buddhas to greet newly arrived monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.5_0: “I hope you are keeping well, monk, I hope you’re comfortable;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.6_0: I hope you’re not tired from traveling.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.7_0: And where have you come from?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.8_0: “I can bear up, Fortunate One, I can carry on, Fortunate One,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.10_0: He then told the Buddha all that had happened at Kīṭāgiri,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.11_0: Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, entered Kīṭāgiri for alms.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.12_0: The lay followers saw me as Kīṭāgiri.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.13_0: Having seen (that), he approached the Fortunate One,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.13_1: They bowed, and respectfully circled me, keeping me on their alms-food.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.14_0: ‘No, reverend, one isn’t gained any alms.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.16_0: That lay follower took me to his house and said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.18_0: ‘I’m going to Sāvatthī to visit the Buddha.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.19_0: Then, would you please pay respect at the Buddha’s feet in my name and say,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.20_0: ‘Venerable Sir, the monastery in Kīṭāgiri has been corrupted.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.21_0: Assaji and Punabbasuka are the resident monks there. They are bad and shameless,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.22_0: and they were misbehaving in this way:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.23_0: They planted flowering trees, watered and plucked them, and then tied the flowers together.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.24_0: Those people who previously had faith and confidence have now lost it,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.25_0: that there is no longer any support for the Sangha,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.26_0: and that the good monks have left and the bad monks are staying on?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.27_0: Sir, please send monks to stay at the monastery at Kīṭāgiri.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.5.28_0: and finished by saying, “That’s where I’ve come from.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.1_0: Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.2_0: “Is it true, monks, that the bad and shameless monks Assaji and Punabbasuka are misbehaving like this at Kīṭāgiri?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.3_0: They planted flowering trees, watered and plucked them, and then tied the flowers together.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.4_0: And is it true that those people who previously had faith and confidence have now lost it,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.5_0: that there is no longer any support for the Sangha,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.6_0: and that the good monks have left and the bad monks are staying on?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.9_0: “Monks, how can those foolish men misbehave like this?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.10_0: plants, flowering trees, and they’ll make the flowers into garlands, garlands, and perfumes.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.11_0: they’ll make the flowers into garlands, garlands with stalks on one side and garlands with stalks on both sides.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.12_0: will makeup, ornaments for the head, ornaments and for the ears, and ornaments for the chest, ornaments, and ornaments for the chest.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.13_0: they’ll carry on with multi-colored women and girls of the daughter-in-laws, these things, ornaments, garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.14_0: will eat from the same plates as these women and drank from the same vessels.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.15_0: will eat at the wrong time, drank alcohol, and cosmetics.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.16_0: will cross the winds and the burn with tooth.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.17_0: While the women were dancing, singing, playing instruments, and performing, so would they.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.18_0: will play around ten board games with eight and ten rows, imaginary board games, hopscotch, spillikins, dice games, tip-cat, painting-with-the-hand games, ball games, toy-pipe games, toy-plow games, turning somersaults, toy-windmill games, toy-measure games, and toy-carriage games, toy-bow gamessing games, letter-guessing games, thought-guessing games of mimicking deformities.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.19_0: They will train in elephant riding, in horsemanship, in carriage riding, in archery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.20_0: And they will cross over the city on the elephants, in front of horses, and in front of them.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.21_0: withered eyes even if they are ranking, boiled, or waists.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.22_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.23_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.24_0: ... After criticizing them, he gave a teaching and addressed Sāriputta and Moggallāna:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.25_0: “Sāriputta, the two of you should go and do a legal procedure of banishing the monks Assaji and Punabbasuka from Kīṭāgiri.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.6.26_0: “Sir, how can we do a procedure of banishing these monks from Kīṭāgiri?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.1_0: “And, monks, this is how it should be done.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.2_0: First you should accuse the monks Assaji and Punabbasuka.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.3_0: They should then be reminded of what they have done, before they are charged with an offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.4_0: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.5_0: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.6_0: These monks, Assaji and Punabbasuka, are corrupters of families and badly behaved.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.6_1: Their bad behavior is seen and heard about,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.6_2: and the families corrupted by them are seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.7_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should do a legal procedure of banishing them from Kīṭāgiri.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.9_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.10_0: These monks, Assaji and Punabbasuka, are corrupters of families and badly behaved.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.10_1: Their bad behavior is seen and heard about,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.10_2: and the families corrupted by them are seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.11_0: The Sangha is doing a legal procedure of banishing them, prohibiting the monks Assaji and Punabbasuka from staying at Kīṭāgiri.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.12_0: Any monk who approves of doing a legal procedure of banishing them from Kīṭāgiri should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.13_0: Any monk who doesn’t agree should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.15_0: For the third time I speak on this matter. Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. ... should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.16_0: The Sangha has performed the legal procedure of banishing them, prohibiting the monks Assaji and Punabbasuka from staying at Kīṭāgiri.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.7.17_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.1_0: Soon afterwards a sangha of monks headed by Sāriputta and Moggallāna went to Kīṭāgiri and did the procedure of banishing those monks, prohibiting the monks Assaji and Punabbasuka from staying at Kīṭāgiri.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.2_0: After the Sangha had done the procedure, those monks did not conduct themselves properly or suitably so as to deserve to be released, nor did they ask the monks for forgiveness. Instead they abused and reviled them, and they slandered them as acting from desire, ill will, confusion, and fear. And they left and they disrobed.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.3_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.4_0: “When the Sangha has done a legal procedure of banishing them, how can these monks act like this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.5_0: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Assaji:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.6_0: “Is it true, monks, that when the Sangha had done a procedure of banishing them, the monks Assaji and Punabbasuka didn’t act properly ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.9_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.10.1_0: ‘If a monk who lives supported by a village or town is a corrupter of families and badly behaved.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.10.1_1: And the bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by them have been seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.11_0: then the monks should correct him like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.12_0: ‘Venerable, you’re a corrupter of families and badly behaved. They have been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.12_1: Your bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.12_2: Leave this monastery; you have stayed here long enough.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.13_0: If that monk spoken to by the monks, he should say,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.14_0: “You’re acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear; because of this sort of offense, you banish some, but not others,”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.15_0: then the monks should correct him like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.16_0: “No, Venerable, don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for it’s not good to misrepresent him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.16_1: and the monks were not acting out of desire.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.16_2: and the monks are not secret hate.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.16_3: But the monks haven’t acted out of delusion.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.16_4: and they were not going to a higher place.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.17_0: Venerable, you’re a corrupter of families and badly behaved.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.17_1: Your bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.17_2: and the families corrupted by them are seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.17_3: Your bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.17_4: Leave this monastery; you have stayed here long enough.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.18_0: If that monk continues as before, the monks should press him up to three times to make him give up that view.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.19_0: If he then stops, all is well.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:1.8.20_0: If he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.1_0: A monk ... a village or town:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.2_0: a village and a town and a city are included in just a village and a town.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.4_0: robes, almsfood, dwellings, and medicines can be obtained in that place.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.6_0: there are four kinds of family: the aristocratic family, the brahmin family, the merchant family, the worker family.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.8_0: Dūsīsayers, (thinking): “Heat, fruits from a bamboo powder, or from a rough fence, or from a pearl, or from a bamboo worker.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.10_0: he plants flowering trees and has it done; he waters them and has it done; he plucks them and has it done; he ties the flowers together and has it done.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.11_0: Has been seen and heard about:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.12_0: those who are present see it; those who are absent hear about it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.14_0: She who was formerly faithful, and who had faith and confidence become without it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.15_0: Has been seen and heard about:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.16_0: those who are present see it; those who are absent hear about it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.18_0: that mendicant who’s a corrupter of families.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.21_0: “Venerable, you’re a corrupter of families and badly behaved.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.21_1: Your bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.21_2: and the families corrupted by them are seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.21_3: Your bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.22_0: If he replies, “You’re acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.22_1: to someone such-and-such a offense, but not others.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.24_0: that monk who is having a legal procedure done against him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.27_0: “No, Venerable, don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for it’s not good to misrepresent him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.27_1: but the monks are not acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.28_0: Venerable, you’re a corrupter of families and badly behaved.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.28_1: Your bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.28_2: and the families corrupted by them are seen and heard about.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.28_3: Your bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.30_0: And they should correct him a third time.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.31_0: If she stops, all is well.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.32_0: If he does not stop, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.33_0: If those who heard about it do not say anything, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.34_0: That monk, even if he has to be pulled into the Sangha, should be corrected like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.35_0: “No, Venerable, don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for it’s not good to misrepresent him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.35_1: but the monks are not acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.36_0: Venerable, you’re a corrupter of families and badly behaved.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.36_1: Your bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.38_0: And they should correct him a third time.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.39_0: If she stops, all is well.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.42_0: “And, monks, he should be pressed like this.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.43_0: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.44_0: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.45_0: The monk so-and-so, who has had a legal procedure of banishment done against himself, is slandering the monks as acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.46_0: And he keeps on doing it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.47_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should press him to make him stop.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.49_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.50_0: The monk so-and-so, who has had a legal procedure of banishment done against himself, is slandering the monks as acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.51_0: And he keeps on doing it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.52_0: The Sangha presses him to make him stop.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.53_0: Any monk who approves of pressing him to make him stop should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.53_1: Any monk who doesn’t agree should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.55_0: For the third time I speak on this matter. ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.56_0: The Sangha has pressed monk so-and-so to stop.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.57_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.58_0: After the motion, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.59_0: After each of the first two announcements, she commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.60_0: When the last announcement is finished, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.61_0: For one who commits the offense entailing suspension, the offense of wrong conduct and the serious offenses are annulled.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.62_0: He commits an offense entailing suspension:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.63_0: only the Sangha gives probation for that offense, sends back to the beginning, gives the trial period, and rehabilitates him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:2.63_2: Therefore it is called “an offense entailing suspension”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.1.1_0: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as such, but he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.1.2_0: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure of it, and he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.1.3_0: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as illegitimate, and he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.1.4_0: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as legitimate, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.1.5_0: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.1.6_0: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, and they perceive it as such, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.1_0: there is no offense for him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.2_0: if she has not been pressed;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.5_0: if he is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.6_0: The thirteenth rule, the training rule on corrupters of families, is finished.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.7_0: “Venerables, the nineteen rules on suspension have been recited; four rules on offenses entailing suspension.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.8_0: If a monk commits any one of them, he is to undergo probation for the same number of days as he knowingly concealed that offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.9_0: When this is completed, he must undertake the trial period for a further six days.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.10_0: When this is completed, he is to be rehabilitated wherever there is an Sangha of at least twenty monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.11_0: If that monk is rehabilitated by an Sangha of even one less than twenty, that monk is not rehabilitated and those monks are at fault. This is the proper procedure.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.12_0: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this?’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.13_0: A second time I ask, ‘Are you pure in this?’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.14_0: A third time I ask, ‘Are you pure in this?’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.15_0: You are pure in this and therefore silent. I will remember it thus.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.16_0: The group of thirteen is finished.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.24_0: Difficult to correct, and corrupters of families:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss13:3.2.26_0: The chapter on offenses entailing suspension is finished.
